reasoning: Cheap, abundant intelligence plus robotized labs enables faster, wider experiment cycles and iteration, raising odds of compressing biomed progress.
Massive compute and low marginal cost make millions of fast, collaborating instances and remote tool/robot control feasible—matching the definition.
As intelligence cost falls, bottlenecks shift to the physical world, data, and law; this framework becomes more relevant.
Scaled AI and automated infrastructure accelerate platform-tool discovery (e.g., CRISPR-like methods) via rapid design–build–test loops.
Cheaper modeling, automated preclinical work, and parallelization help shrink timelines, though human/regulatory limits remain.
Lower intelligence cost boosts health tech, but extreme outcomes (near-elimination, 95% cancer reduction, lifespan ~150) still face biological/regulatory limits.
Scaled AI plus robotics improves neural measurement/intervention and modeling, speeding progress; biology/ethics still constrain.
Lower costs and AI-optimized logistics/robots aid global distribution; success still hinges on coordination and governance.
Cheap intelligence and automated infrastructure raise potential growth and tech diffusion; corruption/policy barriers still bite.
Scale economies and compute chokepoints heighten strategic competition, bolstering the case for an entente despite neutrality re regime type.
If democracies lead, abundant AI strengthens their ability to deliver services, counter propaganda, and improve institutions.
When intelligence becomes cheaper than labor, displacement accelerates and existing structures erode, increasing need for new distribution systems.
Economic flywheels and falling intelligence costs align with a gradual takeoff and the normalization of breakthroughs.
Fast compute buildout and robots building robots make near-term capability milestones more plausible, though timing is uncertain.
Cheaper compute and scaled AI-for-AI research amplify recursive improvement and scientific productivity gains.
Investment flywheels and cost declines are consistent with observed scaling and price drops; specific rates are supported but not guaranteed.
Low-cost intelligence and datacenter scale enable mass replication of competent agents acting as junior coworkers.
Abundant intelligence (and likely energy buildout) supports radical capability expansion while daily human life remains recognizable.
Cheaper intelligence and infrastructure push many goods’ prices down; scarcity/luxury goods see relative price increases.
Making superintelligence cheap and widespread heightens the necessity of alignment as a prerequisite.
Lower-cost AI magnifies both empowerment and misuse; policy pressure toward user control and safeguards increases.
Low marginal cost of intelligence directly supports broad access schemes (e.g., compute budgets) to offset capital–labor skew.
Cheap, scalable intelligence makes marshaling vast cognitive resources by individuals by ~2035 much more feasible.
